image_property.Description: This image illustrates the Ebbinghaus illusion, a visual perception phenomenon. Two orange circles of identical size are surrounded by different contexts of black circles: one with large black circles and the other with small black circles. This contrast in surrounding sizes creates the illusion that the central orange circle on the right, surrounded by larger black circles, appears smaller than the central orange circle on the left, which is surrounded by smaller black circles.

qa_data.Question: The two central orange circles are of different sizes.
The illusion occurs due to color differences between the circles.

What principle does the Ebbinghaus illusion demonstrate? i. The impact of shadow on color perception. ii. The influence of surrounding sizes on perceived size. iii. The difference in color causing visual distortion.
qa_data.Correct Answer: ii. The influence of surrounding sizes on perceived size.

qa_data.Question: If the black circles were removed, what would be observed? i. The orange circles would appear to be the same size. ii. One orange circle would disappear. iii. The orange circles would change color.
qa_data.Correct Answer: i. The orange circles would appear to be the same size.

qa_data.Question: Which visual design principle can be applied to explain the illusion? i. Contrast. ii. Alignment. iii. Proximity.
